title: Artificial Intelligence Summer School - CUNEF Universidad
text:
DATES: 30 June 2025 – 18 July 2025
LOCATION: CUNEF Universidad (PIR 0.5)
TIME: 09 h – 14 h, Monday → Friday
CREDITS: 9 ECTS

title: Artificial Intelligence Summer School - CUNEF Universidad
text:
Objectives

Obtain a global vision of Artificial Intelligence as a widely used technology and discover the challenges and opportunities of its applications. Understand the new way of obtaining, managing and analysing data to generate knowledge and incorporate it into the development of novel intelligent systems.
Reflect, analyse and open the mind to the change in society that we are experiencing to understand its impact on today’s society and find new professions, challenges and opportunities.
Learn to program simple algorithms in Python, to illustrate the foundation of the implementation of intelligent systems using machine learning techniques.
Learn the fundamentals of Generative Artificial Intelligence and the different tools available and their applications in different areas of business.
Learn applications of intelligent systems such as Natural Language Processing and other cutting edge technologies.

title: Artificial Intelligence Summer School - CUNEF Universidad
text:
Methodology
The summer course on artificial intelligence will employ a comprehensive methodology, combining lectures, debates, and hands-on programming sessions. Students will gain theoretical knowledge through expert-led lectures, engage in critical discussions during debates, and apply their learning in practical programming classes. This approach ensures a well-rounded understanding of AI concepts and their real-world applications.

title: Artificial Intelligence Summer School - CUNEF Universidad
text:
Sources
Access to the course materials in the following GitHub repository.

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Python is an interpreted high-level language. It is a multiparadigm language since it supports object-oriented programming, imperative programming, and, to a lesser extent, functional programming. It is a dynamically typed and cross-platform language.

Not compiled: Interpreted
High level: Easy and abstract
Dynamically typed: Variables are not bound to a type (names)
AI: numpy, pandas, scikit-learn, tensorflow, etc.

https://python.org/











Python is the most popular programming language: .





Easy to learn
Compact and understandable code
Widely used (has broad support)
Many libraries






Very high level
Slow (compared to C)
Not strongly typed







Python is used in many fields, such as:

Data Analysis: Pandas, Numpy, etc.
Artificial Intelligence: Machine Learning, Deep Learning, etc.
Web Development: Django, Flask, etc.
Automation: Scripts, bots, etc.
Industry: Automation, IoT, etc.
Games: Pygame, Panda3D, etc.
etc.

Dynamically typed: Variables are not bound to a type (names)

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Installation
There are various ways to work with Python, depending on the environment you want to use, its purpose, and the operating system.

Local: Installation on your own computer

Anaconda: Python distribution that includes libraries and a development environment.
pip: Python package installer.

Online: Online platforms like Google Colab, Jupyter Notebook, etc.

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Interpreter
Python is an interpreted language, meaning that the code is executed line by line. Python can be used as an interactive interpreter where one line of code is executed at a time.

print("Hello World!")

Hello World!


This is usually done from a command terminal:
python

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Python File
The most common use of Python is to write a script in a file with the .py extension. These files are executed via the Python interpreter, which reads and executes the code line by line.

# File: hello.py
s = "Hello World!"
print(s)

Hello World!


To execute the file, use the terminal:
python hello.py

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Jupyter Notebook


Jupyter Notebook is a document format that allows combining text and graphics with Python code. This is the most widely used tool in the fields of data science and machine learning.

Interactive: Runs cell by cell
Visual: Displays graphics and text
Exportable: To HTML, PDF, etc.

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Google Colab


Google Colab is a free platform from Google that allows running Jupyter notebooks in the cloud. It offers many advantages:

Notebook: Works natively with Jupyter notebooks
Online: No installation or updates required
Cloud: Independent of the device (no hardware or compatibility issues)
Dependencies: Includes many pre-installed libraries with consistent versions for all users







Important



This is the recommended platform for the course.

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Variables
Variables in Python are dynamically typed, meaning you don’t specify the variable type when declaring it.

x = 5       # int
y = "Hello" # str
print(x, y)

5 Hello

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Assignment
Values are assigned to variables using the = operator.

x = 5  # x is 5
y = x  # y is 5
x = 3  # x is 3
a, b = x, 2 # a is 3, b is 2
print(x, y, a, b)

3 5 3 2

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Comments
Anything written after a # or within """ is a comment and will not be executed.

x = 5
# This is a comment
# x = 3
""" x = 2 """
print(x)

5

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Data Types
Python has several basic data types:

Numeric: int, float
Text: str
Booleans: bool
Sequences: list, tuple
Sets: set
Dictionaries: dict


x = 5       # int
y = 5.0     # float
z = "Hello" # str
print(type(x), type(y), type(z))

<class 'int'> <class 'float'> <class 'str'>

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Casting
You can change the type of a variable using casting.

x = 5       # int
y = str(x)  # str
print(y, type(y))

5 <class 'str'>

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Arithmetic Operators

x = 5   # int
y = 2   # int
print(x + y)  # Add
print(x - y)  # Subtract
print(x * y)  # Multiply
print(x / y)  # Divide
print(x % y)  # Modulus
print(x ** y) # Exponentiation
print(x // y) # Floor division

7
3
10
2.5
1
25
2

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Logical Operators

x = True   # bool
y = False  # bool
print(not x)   # Not
print(x and y) # And
print(x or y)  # Or

False
False
True


0, empty strings, empty lists, etc., are considered False in Python.

x = 0   # int -> False
y = ""  # str -> False
print(bool(x), bool(y))

False False

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Comparison Operators

x = 5  # int
y = 2  # int
print(x == y) # Equal
print(x != y) # Not equal
print(x > y)  # Greater than
print(x >= y) # Greater than or equal
print(x < y)  # Less than
print(x is y) # Same object

False
True
True
True
False
False

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Lists
Lists are an ordered and mutable collection of elements.

l = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  # list
print(l)

[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Lists - Accessing Elements
To access an element in a list, use the [] operator.

l = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
print(l[0])   # First element
print(l[-1])  # Last element
print(l[1:3]) # Slice [2,3]

1
5
[2, 3]

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Lists - Modification
Elements in a list can be modified by accessing them with []. Lists can also be extended using append and concatenated with +.

l = [1, 2]  # list
print(l)
l[0] = 0    # l = [0,2]
print(l)
l.append(3) # l = [0,2,3]
print(l)
l = l + l   # l = [0,2,3,0,2,3]
print(l)

[1, 2]
[0, 2]
[0, 2, 3]
[0, 2, 3, 0, 2, 3]

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Tuples
Tuples are an ordered and immutable collection of elements. They are accessed like lists but cannot be modified.

t = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
print(t)
print(t[1:3])

(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
(2, 3)

title: Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Strings
Strings are tuples of characters with specific methods.

s = "Hello World!"
print(s)
print(s[0])
print(s[1:5])

Hello World!
H
ello

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
String - Methods

s = "Hello World!"
print(s.upper())
print(s.lower())
print(s.replace("H", "J"))
print(s.split(" "))
print(s.find("W"))

HELLO WORLD!
hello world!
Jello World!
['Hello', 'World!']
6

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Blocks
Code blocks in Python are defined by indentation (spaces or tabs at the beginning of a line). Therefore, it is very important to maintain the correct indentation.

if True:
    print("Block 1")
    if False:
        print("Block 2")
print("Block 3")

Block 1
Block 3

title: Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
text:
While Loop
The while loop runs as long as the condition is true.

x = 0
while x < 5:
    print(x)
    x += 1

0
1
2
3
4

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
For Loop
The for loop is used to iterate over a sequence.

l = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
for x in l:
    print(x)

1
2
3
4
5

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
For Loop - Range
The range function generates a sequence of numbers.

for x in range(5):
    print(x)

0
1
2
3
4

title: Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Functions
Functions in Python are defined using the def keyword. They are used to encapsulate and reuse code.

def my_function():
    print("Hello from a function")

my_function()
my_function()

Hello from a function
Hello from a function

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Functions - Arguments
Functions can take arguments, which are passed when calling the function. Arguments can be used by position or by name. Default arguments can also be defined, which are used if not explicitly specified when calling the function.

def my_function(name, age=25):
    print(f"Hello {name}, you are {age} years old")

my_function("Alice")
my_function(age=30, name="Bob")

Hello Alice, you are 25 years old
Hello Bob, you are 30 years old

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Functions - Return
Functions can return a value using the return keyword.

def my_function(x):
    return x * 2

print(my_function(3))
print(my_function(5))

6
10

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Built-in Functions
These are some frequently used built-in functions in Python:

print: Prints to the screen
range: Returns an iterable sequence of numbers
len: Returns the length of an iterable or container
input: Reads from the keyboard
sum: Returns the sum of elements in an iterable
min: Returns the minimum of elements in an iterable
max: Returns the maximum of elements in an iterable
any: Returns True if any element in an iterable is True
all: Returns True if all elements in an iterable are True
sorted: Returns a sorted list of elements in an iterable

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Classes
To create more complex data structures, you can use classes. The class keyword is used to define a class.

class MyClass:
    x = 5

c = MyClass()
print(c.x)

5

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Classes - Methods
Classes can have methods, which are functions that belong to the class. The first argument of a method is the object calling it, conventionally called self.

class MyClass:
    def my_method(self):
        print("Hello from a method")

c = MyClass()
c.my_method()

Hello from a method

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Classes - Built-in Methods
There are several special methods that can be defined in a class:

__init__: Class constructor
__str__: String representation of the class
__len__: Length of the class
__getitem__: Access elements using []
etc.

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
List Comprehension
List comprehension is a quick and compact way to create lists.

l1 = [x for x in range(5)]
print(l1)

l2 = [x for x in range(5) if x % 2]
print(l2)

[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
[1, 3]

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Lambda
Lambda is a way to define anonymous functions in a single line.

f = lambda x: x * 2
print(f(3))

# Sort by the second element
l = [(1, 2), (3, 1), (5, 3)]
l.sort(key=lambda x: x[1])

6

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Enumerate
enumerate is a function that returns an iterable with indices and values.

l = ["a", "b", "c"]
for i, x in enumerate(l):
    print(i, x)

0 a
1 b
2 c

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Working with Dictionaries
Dictionaries can be iterated by key, value, or both.

d = {"a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3}
for k in d.keys():
    print(k)

for v in d.values():
    print(v)

for k, v in d.items():
    print(k, v)

a
b
c
1
2
3
a 1
b 2
c 3

title: Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Iterating Over Multiple Values
You can create loops that iterate over more than one iterable at a time when the iterable is a collection. The zip function creates an iterable that groups elements from the iterables it is passed.

l1 = [1, 2, 3]
l2 = ["a", "b", "c"]
for x, y in zip(l1, l2):
    print(x, y)

1 a
2 b
3 c

title: Fundamental algorithms I
Fundamental algorithms I
text:
Much More
The Python language is very extensive and has many more features and functionalities. This topic provides a basic overview of the main ideas and the most commonly used elements of the language.
We encourage students to explore more about the language and delve deeper into areas that interest them the most.

title: SNAKE GAME
text:
SnakeGame


The Snake Game is a classic video game genre that has been popular since the 1970s. The player controls a snake that moves around the screen, eating food and growing longer while avoiding collisions with itself.
Try it out here.

# GAME CODE
from typing import Tuple
import random
import time
import copy
from collections import deque
from IPython.display import clear_output
import ipywidgets as widgets


class SnakeMap:
    def __init__(self, n, head, body, fruit):
        self.n = n
        self.head = head
        self.body = body
        self.fruit = fruit

    def move_snake(self, direction: str, rng) -> Tuple[int, "SnakeMap"]:
        d = direction.upper()

        new_head = self.head.copy()
        new_body = self.body.copy()
        new_fruit = self.fruit.copy()
        result = 0

        # Move head (wrap-around)
        if d == "U":
            new_head[0] = (self.head[0] - 1) % self.n
        elif d == "D":
            new_head[0] = (self.head[0] + 1) % self.n
        elif d == "R":
            new_head[1] = (self.head[1] + 1) % self.n
        elif d == "L":
            new_head[1] = (self.head[1] - 1) % self.n
        else:
            raise Exception(f"{direction!r} is not valid (use U, D, L or R)")

        # Fruit?
        fruit_eaten = new_head == self.fruit
        if fruit_eaten:
            new_fruit = self.create_fruit(rng)
            result = 1

        # Update body
        new_body.insert(0, self.head)
        if not fruit_eaten:
            new_body.pop()

        # Collision
        if new_head in new_body:
            result = -1

        return result, SnakeMap(
            self.n,
            new_head,
            new_body,
            new_fruit
        )

    def _arrow_towards(self, src: list[int], dst: list[int]) -> str:
        r, c = src
        if (r - 1) % self.n == dst[0]:
            return "^"
        if (r + 1) % self.n == dst[0]:
            return "v"
        if (c - 1) % self.n == dst[1]:
            return "<"
        if (c + 1) % self.n == dst[1]:
            return ">"
        return "·"

    def _render(self) -> str:
        grid = [[" "] * self.n for _ in range(self.n)]

        # Head
        grid[self.head[0]][self.head[1]] = "O"

        # Body (arrows) – each segment points to the segment closer to head
        for idx, seg in enumerate(self.body):
            prev = self.head if idx == 0 else self.body[idx - 1]
            r, c = seg
            grid[r][c] = self._arrow_towards(seg, prev)

        # Fruit
        fr, fc = self.fruit
        grid[fr][fc] = "X"

        # Assemble ASCII
        border = "+" + "-" * (2 * self.n) + "+"
        rows = [border]
        for row in grid:
            rows.append("|" + "".join(f"{ch} " for ch in row) + "|")
        rows.append(border)

        return "\n".join(rows)

    def __str__(self):
        return self._render()

    def create_fruit(self, rng):
        free = [
            (r, c)
            for r in range(self.n)
            for c in range(self.n)
            if [r, c] != self.head and [r, c] not in self.body
        ]
        if not free:
            raise Exception("Board is full! You win!")
        return list(rng.choice(free))



class SnakeGame:
    def __init__(self, initial_map = None, seed = 42):
        self.initial_map = initial_map or SnakeMap(n=4, head=[0, 2], body=[[0, 1], [0, 0]], fruit=[3,3])
        self.seed = seed

    def str_score(self, score: int, step: int):
        """Print the current score and step count."""
        return f"Steps: {step}  Score: {score}"

    def str_separator(self, n=50):
        """Print a separator line."""
        return "=" * n

    # ------------------------------------------------------------------ #
    # Real-time loop (animated)                                          #
    # ------------------------------------------------------------------ #
    def game_loop(self, policy, max_steps: int = 50, delay: float = 0.5, history_size: int = 1):
        history = deque(maxlen=history_size)
        map = copy.deepcopy(self.initial_map)
        rng = random.Random(self.seed)
        score = 0
        step = 0

        try:
            while step < max_steps:
                move = policy(map)
                result, map = map.move_snake(move, rng)

                if result == 1:
                    score += 1

                elif result == -1:
                    print(self.str_separator())
                    print("Game over! Snake collided with itself.")
                    break

                step += 1

                clear_output(wait=True)
                print("\n\n".join(history))
                print(self.str_separator())

                render = map._render()
                print(move)
                print(render)
                print(self.str_score(score, step))

                history.append(render)

                time.sleep(delay)

            print(self.str_separator())
            print("Maximum steps achieved!")

        except Exception as exc:
            print(self.str_separator())
            print(exc)
            raise exc

        finally:
            print(self.str_score(score, step))



    # ------------------------------------------------------------------ #
    # Interactive slider loop                                            #
    # ------------------------------------------------------------------ #
    def interact_loop(self, policy, max_steps: int = 50):
        # ---------- simulation part (unchanged) ----------
        map_ = copy.deepcopy(self.initial_map)   # `map` is a Python builtin
        rng = random.Random(self.seed)
        score = 0
        step = 0
        movements = ""

        def frame_to_store(movements, map_, score, step, info=""):
            return (
                movements + "\n" +
                map_._render() + "\n" +
                self.str_score(score, step) + "\n" +
                info
            )

        frames = [frame_to_store(movements, map_, score, step)]

        while step < max_steps:
            try:
                move = policy(map_)

                for l in move:
                    result, map_ = map_.move_snake(l, rng)
                    movements += l
                    step += 1

                    if result == 1:
                        score += 1
                    elif result == -1:
                        frames.append(frame_to_store(
                            movements, map_, score, step,
                            "Game over! Snake collided with itself."))
                        break

                frames.append(frame_to_store(movements, map_, score, step))
                movements += " "

            except Exception as exc:
                frames.append(frame_to_store(
                    movements, map_, score, step, f"{exc}"))
                break

        # ---------- widgets part (changed) ----------
        slider = widgets.IntSlider(
            value=0, min=0, max=len(frames)-1, step=1,
            description="step", readout=True, layout=widgets.Layout(width="50%")
        )

        play = widgets.Play(
            value=0, min=0, max=len(frames)-1, step=1,
            interval=500,              # milliseconds between frames
            description="Play",        # button text
            disabled=False
        )

        # keep the two widgets in sync
        widgets.jslink((play, 'value'), (slider, 'value'))

        # what happens when the index changes
        out = widgets.Output()

        def _show(change):
            with out:
                out.clear_output(wait=True)
                print(frames[change['new']])

        slider.observe(_show, names='value')      # respond to slider (and play)

        # display everything nicely
        controls = widgets.HBox([play, slider])
        display(widgets.VBox([controls, out]))


CREATE YOUR OWN SNAKE STRATEGY
Your task is to create a Python function that plays the Snake Game for you. Try to eat as many fruits as possible while avoiding eating yourself.
In the function my_snake you can implement your own snake strategy. Receving a map state, you must decide between 4 possible actions: - UP - DOWN - LEFT - RIGHT

def my_snake(map):
    # IMPLEMENT YOUR CODE HERE
    return "UR"  # Example: always move up

game = SnakeGame()
game.interact_loop(my_snake, max_steps=20)
